The transmission characteristics of SARS-CoV-2 were similar to those of SARS-CoV and influenza viruses, highlighting the potential for global spread.
58 As of April 17, 2020, data from WHO showed that 2,158,033 confirmed cases had been identified in at least 200 countries, areas or territories, compared with the total of 24,727 on March 8, 2020. Specifically, the worst-affected countries were the US, Spain, Italy, Germany, and China. The number of the deaths was 67,840, which exceeds the number for SARS in 2002 (8,273 confirmed, 775 deaths) and MERS in 2012 (1,139 confirmed, 431 deaths). On March 12, 2020, WHO Director-General, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, declared the COVID-19 outbreak a global pandemic, marking a further escalation of this epidemic.
